description: This course is intended for students in mechanical engineering, civil-systems, materials science, and other fields. It continues the treatment of the statics of rigid bodies begun in Physics 150 and MEAM 110 and leads to the treatment of deformable bodies and their response to loads. The concepts of stress, strain, and linearly elastic response are introduced and they are applied to the behavior of rods, beams, shafts and pressure valves. Safety factors and the onset of mechanical failure are discussed. The course incorporates the use of computers to solve problems, and includes a written library research assignment and a team design project.
name: STATICS & STRENTH OF MAT

values.comments:
This course is intended for students in mechanical engineering, civil-systems,
materials science, and other fields. It continues the treatment of the statics of rigid bodies
begun in Physics 150 and MEAM 110 and leads to the treatment of deformable bodies
and their response to loads. The concepts of stress, strain, and linearly elastic response
are introduced and they are applied to the behavior of rods, beams, shafts and pressure
valves. Safety factors and the onset of mechanical failure are discussed. The course
incorporates the use of computers to solve problems, and includes a written library
research assignment and a team design project.
Overall, students felt this course taught them a lot about statistics and static
systems. Students appreciated the class’s applications of the mechanical engineering
perspective. However, some students felt that the course focused too much on textbook
problems rather than those they would encounter outside of the classroom.
Students expressed that the grading was “consistent and fair” in this course.
Many students felt that Professor Jackson did not “communicate well during lectures,”
“[breezing] through” many problems when it would have been much more helpful to
slowly work through a few. Attendance dropped during the semester as students
developed a “lack of interest” in the material.
This course builds on the prerequisite course MEAM 110. Many students
appreciated the structure and format of the class, where there are weekly quizzes and
assignments, no midterms, and one final. Students felt that having quizzes every week
kept them “on top of things.” The textbook for the course was not very helpful, as “it
arrives at equations without a good explanation as to how the derivation was achieved.”
